true to have the new stream dispose the wrapped stream when it is disposed.

member.summary: Efficiently pumps data from a sparse stream to another stream.

Whether to transfer responsibility for calling Dispose on toWrap.

member.name: M:DiscUtils.SparseStream.Clear(System.Int32)
member.summary: Clears bytes from the stream.
member.param: The number of bytes (from the current position) to clear.

remarks.para: Logically equivalent to writing count null/zero bytes to the stream, some implementations determine that some (or all) of the range indicated is not actually stored. There is no direct, automatic, correspondence to clearing bytes and them not being represented as an 'extent' - for example, the implementation of the underlying stream may not permit fine-grained extent storage.
It is always safe to call this method to 'zero-out' a section of a stream, regardless of the underlying stream implementation.

member.name: M:DiscUtils.SparseStream.GetExtentsInRange(System.Int64,System.Int64)
member.summary: Gets the parts of a stream that are stored, within a specified range.
member.param: The offset of the first byte of interest.
The number of bytes of interest.
member.returns: An enumeration of stream extents, indicating stored bytes.

member.name: P:DiscUtils.SparseStream.Extents
member.summary: Gets the parts of the stream that are stored.
member.remarks: This may be an empty enumeration if all bytes are zero.

member.name: T:DiscUtils.MappedStream
member.summary: Base class for streams that are essentially a mapping onto a parent stream.
member.remarks: This class provides access to the mapping underlying the stream, enabling callers to convert a byte range in this stream into one or more ranges in the parent stream.

member.name: M:DiscUtils.MappedStream.FromStream(System.IO.Stream,DiscUtils.Ownership)
member.summary: Converts any stream into a non-linear stream.
member.param: The stream to convert.
true to have the new stream dispose the wrapped stream when it is disposed.
member.remarks: The wrapped stream is assumed to be a linear stream (such that any byte range maps directly onto the parent stream).

member.name: M:DiscUtils.MappedStream.FromStream(System.IO.Stream,DiscUtils.Ownership,System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{DiscUtils.StreamExtent})
member.summary: Converts any stream into a non-linear stream.
member.param: The stream to convert.
true to have the new stream dispose the wrapped stream when it is disposed.
The set of extents actually stored in stream.
member.remarks: The wrapped stream is assumed to be a linear stream (such that any byte range maps directly onto the parent stream).

member.name: M:DiscUtils.MappedStream.MapContent(System.Int64,System.Int64)
member.summary: Maps a logical range down to storage locations.
member.param: The first logical range to map.
The length of the range to map.
member.returns: One or more stream extents specifying the storage locations that correspond to the identified logical extent range.

remarks.para: As far as possible, the stream extents are returned in logical disk order - however, due to the nature of non-linear streams, not all of the range may actually be stored, or some or all of the range may be compressed - thus reading the returned stream extents is not equivalent to reading the logical disk range.

member.name: M:DiscUtils.IBuffer.Clear(System.Int64,System.Int32)
member.summary: Clears bytes from the buffer.
member.param: The start offset within the buffer.
The number of bytes to clear.

remarks.para: Logically equivalent to writing count null/zero bytes to the buffer, some implementations determine that some (or all) of the range indicated is not actually stored. There is no direct, automatic, correspondence to clearing bytes and them not being represented as an 'extent' - for example, the implementation of the underlying stream may not permit fine-grained extent storage.
It is always safe to call this method to 'zero-out' a section of a buffer, regardless of the underlying buffer implementation.

member.name: T:DiscUtils.Iso9660.Iso9660Variant
member.summary: Enumeration of known file system variants.

remarks.para: ISO9660 has a number of significant limitations, and over time multiple schemes have been devised for extending the standard to support the richer file system semantics typical of most modern operating systems. These variants differ functionally and (in the case of RockRidge) may represent a logically different directory hierarchy to that encoded in the vanilla iso9660 standard.
Use this enum to control which variants to honour / prefer when accessing an ISO image.

member.name: F:DiscUtils.Iso9660.Iso9660Variant.None
member.summary: No known variant.

member.summary: Vanilla ISO9660.

member.summary: Joliet file system (Windows).

member.name: F:DiscUtils.Iso9660.Iso9660Variant.RockRidge
member.summary: Rock Ridge (Unix).

member.name: M:DiscUtils.BufferStream.Clear(System.Int32)
member.summary: Clears bytes from the stream.
member.param: The number of bytes (from the current position) to clear.

remarks.para: Logically equivalent to writing count null/zero bytes to the stream, some implementations determine that some (or all) of the range indicated is not actually stored. There is no direct, automatic, correspondence to clearing bytes and them not being represented as an 'extent' - for example, the implementation of the underlying stream may not permit fine-grained extent storage.
It is always safe to call this method to 'zero-out' a section of a stream, regardless of the underlying stream implementation.

member.name: T:DiscUtils.StreamPump

member.remarks: This class is aware of sparse streams, and will avoid copying data that is not valid in the source stream. This functionality should normally only be used when the destination stream is known not to contain any existing data.

member.name: T:DiscUtils.ThreadSafeStream
member.summary: Provides a thread-safe wrapping around a sparse stream.

remarks.para: Streams are inherently not thread-safe (because read/write is not atomic w.r.t. Position). This method enables multiple 'views' of a stream to be created (each with their own Position), and ensures only a single operation is executing on the wrapped stream at any time.
This example shows the pattern of use:
This results in 11 streams that can be used in different streams - tss and ten 'views' created from tss.
Note, the stream length cannot be changed.

member.remarks: Some file system, such as FAT, don't have a defined way to convert from file system time (local time where the file system is authored) to UTC time. This parameter determines the algorithm to use.

member.name: T:DiscUtils.DiscFileSystemOptions

member.remarks: Not all options are honoured by all file systems.

member.name: M:DiscUtils.DiscFileSystemOptions.#ctor

member.remarks: You shouldn't normally create a new instance. File systems will provide an instance of the correct derived type.

member.name: P:DiscUtils.DiscFileSystemOptions.RandomNumberGenerator
member.summary: Gets or sets the random number generator the file system should use.
member.remarks: This option is normally null, which is fine for most purposes. Use this option when you need to finely control the filesystem for reproducibility of behaviour (for example in a test harness).

member.name: P:DiscUtils.SparseMemoryBuffer.AllocatedChunks
member.summary: Gets the (sorted) list of allocated chunks, as chunk indexes.
member.remarks: This method returns chunks as an index rather than absolute stream position. For example, if ChunkSize is 16KB, and the first 32KB of the buffer is actually stored, this method will return 0 and 1. This indicates the first and second chunks are stored.

member.summary: Gets the content of the disk as a stream.
member.remarks: Note the returned stream is not guaranteed to be at any particular position. The actual position will depend on the last partition table/file system activity, since all access to the disk contents pass through a single stream instance. Set the stream position before accessing the stream.

member.name: P:DiscUtils.VirtualDisk.IsPartitioned
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the disk appears to have a valid partition table.
member.remarks: There is no reliable way to determine whether a disk has a valid partition table. The 'guess' consists of checking for basic indicators and looking for obviously invalid data, such as overlapping partitions.

member.name: P:DiscUtils.VirtualDisk.Partitions
member.summary: Gets the object that interprets the partition structure.
member.remarks: It is theoretically possible for a disk to contain two independent partition structures - a BIOS/GPT one and an Apple one, for example. This method will return in order of preference, a GUID partition table, a BIOS partition table, then in undefined preference one of any other partition tables found. See PartitionTable.GetPartitionTables to gain access to all the discovered partition tables on a disk.

member.name: T:DiscUtils.VirtualDiskLayer
member.summary: Represents the base layer, or a differencing layer of a VirtualDisk.

remarks.para: VirtualDisks are composed of one or more layers - a base layer which represents the entire disk (even if not all bytes are actually stored), and a number of differencing layers that store the disk sectors that are logically different to the base layer.
Disk Layers may not store all sectors. Any sectors that are not stored are logically zero's (for base layers), or holes through to the layer underneath (all other layers).

member.summary: Creates a new partition that encompasses the entire disk.
member.param: The partition type.
Whether the partition is active (bootable).
member.remarks: The partition table must be empty before this method is called, otherwise IOException is thrown.

member.name: M:DiscUtils.Partitions.GuidPartitionTable.Create(System.Int64,DiscUtils.Partitions.WellKnownPartitionType,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Creates a new primary partition with a target size.
member.param: The target size (in bytes).
The partition type.
Whether the partition is active (bootable).
member.returns: The index of the new partition.

member.name: M:DiscUtils.Partitions.GuidPartitionTable.CreateAligned(DiscUtils.Partitions.WellKnownPartitionType,System.Boolean,System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates a new aligned partition that encompasses the entire disk.
member.param: The partition type.
Whether the partition is active (bootable).
The alignment (in bytes).
member.remarks: The partition table must be empty before this method is called, otherwise IOException is thrown.

Traditionally partitions were aligned to the physical structure of the underlying disk, however with modern storage greater efficiency is acheived by aligning partitions on large values that are a power of two.

member.name: M:DiscUtils.Partitions.GuidPartitionTable.CreateAligned(System.Int64,DiscUtils.Partitions.WellKnownPartitionType,System.Boolean,System.Int32)

The partition type.
Whether the partition is active (bootable).
The alignment (in bytes).
member.returns: The index of the new partition.
member.remarks: Traditionally partitions were aligned to the physical structure of the underlying disk, however with modern storage greater efficiency is achieved by aligning partitions on large values that are a power of two.

member.name: T:DiscUtils.VolumeManager
member.summary: VolumeManager interprets partitions and other on-disk structures (possibly combining multiple disks).

remarks.para: Although file systems commonly are placed directly within partitions on a disk, in some cases a logical volume manager / logical disk manager may be used, to combine disk regions in multiple ways for data redundancy or other purposes.
